title: 107_hr1984
content: The "English Language Unity Act of 2001" declares English as the official language of the United States, recognizing the diverse backgrounds of its citizens while emphasizing the importance of the English language as a unifying factor. The "English Language Unity Act of 2001" establishes English as the official language of the United States by amending Title 4, United States Code to include a new chapter on the official language. The English Language Unity Act of 2001 designates English as the official language of the United States for all government functions and activities, excluding language teaching and requirements under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The Uniform English language rule for naturalization requires citizens to be able to read and understand English text of key documents like the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution. This rule excludes certain actions related to national security, public health, census compilation, victim rights, and non-English terms. The Uniform English language rule for naturalization mandates that all ceremonies be conducted in English. It also clarifies that official functions can be performed in languages other than English, preserves Native Alaskan and Native American languages, and encourages the learning and use of languages other than English. The Uniform English language rule for naturalization requires ceremonies to be in English and allows official functions in other languages. It supports Native Alaskan and Native American languages and promotes learning languages other than English. Chapter 6 discusses the official language of the United States, emphasizing the general rules of construction for English language texts of the laws. Chapter 1 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to include new section 8, which establishes general rules of construction for laws of the United States. Any ambiguity in the English language text of the laws shall be resolved in accordance with the last two articles of the Bill of Rights. Additionally, implementing regulations are to be put in place. The Department of Justice must issue a proposed rule for testing English language ability for naturalization within 180 days. The rule should ensure candidates can read and understand key U.S. documents. Exceptions to the standard should be limited to extraordinary circumstances like asylum. The effective date for the amendments is 180 days after the Act's enactment.
